clause_text: Mrs. Baker was known as the cat lady
in the narrator's childhood neighborhood
She had adopted
or provided homes
for at least twenty cats
Mrs. Baker was known for adopting many cats
She had a young grandson
who attempted to befriend the narrator
The narrator, a tomboy, was oblivious to his attempts at friendship
The grandson was perceived as having poor manners
Mrs. Baker, known as the cat lady, had adopted at least twenty cats
Her young grandson attempted to befriend the narrator, who was a tomboy
The grandson had poor manners, which the narrator did not appreciate
The grandson left a note about running away
leading to a search initiated by the narrator and Mrs. Baker
Mrs. Baker, known as the cat lady, had a young grandson
trying to befriend the narrator
The grandson had poor manners
which made the narrator reluctant to befriend him
The grandson left a note
about running away due to nagging about the narrator
prompting a search
Mrs. Baker and the narrator searched near the old mill
but found no trace of the grandson
Mrs. Baker, known as the cat lady, had a young grandson
trying to befriend the narrator
The grandson had poor manners
which made the narrator reluctant to befriend him
The grandson left a note
about running away due to nagging
prompting a search
The search ended
when they found the grandson in the treehouse
not having run away
Mrs. Baker, known for adopting many cats, had a poorly mannered grandson
trying to befriend the narrator
The grandson left a note
threatening to run away
due to his grandmother's nagging about the narrator
The narrator and Mrs. Baker searched for the grandson
and found him safe in the treehouse
Officer Dawson warned the narrator
to stay out of sight
because Mrs. Baker never forgets
